title: Add closed-state check to HasPlugin for defensive consistency
description:
## Summary
HasPlugin does not check closed state, unlike other ExtismHost methods.

## Problem
After Close() is called, h.plugins is set to nil. HasPlugin returns false (correct behavior) but doesn't explicitly check h.closed like LoadPlugin and DeliverEvent do.

## Solution
Add closed-state check to HasPlugin for defensive consistency:
```go
func (h *ExtismHost) HasPlugin(name string) bool {
    h.mu.RLock()
    defer h.mu.RUnlock()
    if h.closed {
        return false
    }
    _, ok := h.plugins[name]
    return ok
}
```

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_host.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] HasPlugin checks h.closed before accessing plugins map
- [ ] Test: `TestExtismHost_HasPlugin_AfterClose` verifies behavior
- [ ] Consistent with LoadPlugin and DeliverEvent patterns

title: Investigate Python PDK plugin reuse state corruption
description:
## Summary
When the Python echo plugin is called multiple times in rapid succession within the same ExtismHost, wasm memory errors occur:
- `out of bounds memory access`
- `invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference`

The Rust alloc plugin handles reuse fine, suggesting this is Python PDK-specific.

## Impact
- Plugins may need to be single-use or require host instance isolation
- Could affect production plugin reliability under load

## Investigation Tasks
- [ ] Determine if this is Extism Go SDK behavior or Python PDK behavior
- [ ] Test with other PDKs (Rust, JavaScript) for comparison
- [ ] Check Extism documentation for plugin instance lifecycle
- [ ] Determine if `plugin.Reset()` or similar is needed between calls
- [ ] Document findings and recommended patterns

## Workarounds
- Use separate ExtismHost instances per plugin (current test approach)
- Avoid rapid sequential calls to same plugin

## References
- Observed in TestExtismSubscriber_MultiplePatterns test
- Related epic: holomush-qmt (Extism Phase 1)

description:
Implement Extism-based plugin framework per design in docs/plans/2026-01-18-extism-plugin-framework-design.md

## Summary

Replace wazero with Extism to dramatically simplify plugin authoring and establish a plugin-first architecture where all game commands and behaviors are plugins.

## Key Deliverables

**Phase 1: Core Extism Integration**
- Replace wazero with Extism Go SDK
- Basic DeliverEvent with OTel tracing
- Port echo plugin to Python (proof of concept)

**Phase 2: Host Functions**
- Game query functions (query_location, query_character, etc.)
- emit_event host function
- Capability model and manifest parsing

**Phase 3: External Access**
- HTTP functions with domain allowlist
- KV storage for plugin state
- Rate limiting

**Phase 4: Schema & Commands**
- Schema contributions (attributes, tables)
- Migration system
- Command registration
- Load order resolution

**Phase 5: Bundled Plugins**
- Extract core commands to replaceable plugins
- holomush-communication, holomush-navigation, etc.

## Architecture Decisions

- Micro-core: events, sessions, auth, plugin host, DB, object model only
- All commands/behaviors as plugins
- Explicit load order with priority-based conflict resolution
- OTel tracing for all plugin calls

title: Add goroutine lifecycle management to ExtismSubscriber
description:
## Summary
ExtismSubscriber spawns goroutines without lifecycle management, risking goroutine leaks on shutdown.

## Problem
HandleEvent spawns goroutines for each plugin but has no:
- WaitGroup to track in-flight deliveries
- Stop() method to wait for goroutines
- Context propagation for cancellation

Compare to wazero PluginSubscriber which has proper Start()/Stop() lifecycle.

## Solution
Add lifecycle management:
```go
type ExtismSubscriber struct {
    // ... existing fields
    wg     sync.WaitGroup
    ctx    context.Context
    cancel context.CancelFunc
}

func (s *ExtismSubscriber) Stop() {
    s.cancel()
    s.wg.Wait()
}
```

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_subscriber.go
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_subscriber_test.go

title: Fix thread safety: hold RLock during entire DeliverEvent call
description:
## Summary
ExtismHost.DeliverEvent releases the RLock before using the plugin pointer, creating a race condition if Close() is called concurrently.

## Problem
```go
h.mu.RLock()
p, ok := h.plugins[pluginName]
h.mu.RUnlock()  // Lock released before using p

if \!ok { ... }
if \!p.FunctionExists("handle_event") { ... }  // p used outside lock
```

If Close() is called after RUnlock() but before p.Call(), the plugin could be invalidated.

## Solution
Hold the read lock for the entire DeliverEvent call, consistent with wazero PluginHost pattern.

## Files
- Modify: internal/wasm/extism_host.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] RLock held from plugin lookup through p.Call() completion
- [ ] Test: `TestExtismHost_DeliverEvent_ConcurrentClose` demonstrates no race
- [ ] Run with `go test -race` passes
- [ ] Code review confirms fix
